awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Protecting Privacy of Biometric Data throughout Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Progress in computer vision makes biometric authentication and recognition become more reliable and readily available than before, with a potential for ubiquitous use of such data well beyond traditional authentication. The need to protect highly sensitive biometrics is apparent, which, unlike other types of data used for authentication purposes, cannot be revoked and replaced with a new value. This means that any breach in security of biometric data has far reaching consequences to the individual than loss of other sensitive data.

Previously, only limited mechanisms for protecting privacy of biometry were available. To address the paucity of adequate protection mechanisms, this project develops novel techniques for enhancing privacy protection of biometric data when it is being processed and used in environments which are not fully trusted or secured in a broad set of contexts and applications that go well beyond comparing two biometric codes. The project's scope covers (i) secure interactive computation on biometric data, (ii) secure outsourcing of biometric computation to untrusted servers, and (iii) efficient verification of the correctness of the result of outsourced computation. A distinct benefit of this work is that it combines cryptographic design with practical evaluation on real biometric data, as well as includes integration of developed tools into a biometric computing grid environment. The outcomes of this research are expected to enable and promote safer practices in handing sensitive biometric data, including utilizing untrusted computing power, and a wider degree of collaboration between entities who are otherwise not permitted to share their data.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research project was to design new techniques for securely evaluating a wide range of functionalities used for processing different types of biometric data. In particular, the security requirements are such that any biometric data handled by any developed algorithm or protocol is provably protected via cryptographic means throughout the duration of the computation. Furthermore, when the computation is delegated to a third-party cloud computing provider, the result of the computation can be efficiently verified for correctness without re-executing the task.

This project has been instrumental in advancing our knowledge of privacy-preserving and verifiable computation with biometric data and has resulted in a corpus of novel cryptographic and algorithmic techniques for supporting secure computation with a number of common biometric modalities such as iris, fingerprints, DNA, and voice. The techniques developed as part of this research go beyond their application to biometric computation, and specific findings of this research include:

1) Techniques for securely comparing two fingerprint images built upon conventional fingerprint comparison algorithms of high accuracy including fingerprint alignment over private data.

2) Techniques for facilitating secure statistical tests over genomic data for genome-wide association and linkage studies.

3) Techniques of improved efficiency for computing a number of genomic tests over private data in the server-aided setting, where existence of a not fully trusted third-party service provider greatly improves performance.

4) Techniques for securely performing speaker or speech authentication, where the server performing authentication never has access to biometric-derived data in the clear.

5) Techniques for efficiently comparing two or more private iris images including secure and robust outsourcing of such functionalities.

6) Techniques for efficiently verifying the result of large-scale biometric computations outsourced to cloud providers for a number of biometric modalities.

The broader impacts of this research on the society are that the techniques developed in the course of this project lead to safer use of highly sensitive biometric data and minimize unintended data disclosure. The techniques are of utmost importance when the computation is carried out in not fully trusted environments such as computation outsourcing to cloud computing providers or running computation on distributed data sets owned by different entities. The techniques are however also applicable when the participating parties are trusted and in such circumstances help protect the data from unintended abuse by insiders or through malware infections. This project also provided extensive training and mentoring to a number of graduate and undergraduate students involved in this research and it supported unique student knowledge exchanges for students from a number of universities working on different aspects of privacy protection.
